content.description: Start at waist height in the crack, and climb up. There is nice rock on this one.
content.location:
If facing

The Sail

, this is around the right side of the boulder.

content.description:
The Sail is a very interesting compression climb. Start with your left hand around waist height on a sloper and your right hand low in the crack about 3 inches under the diagonal curve in the crack. Climb up the compression feature. A toehook out right helps with the crux at the top. Utilize crimps, meat-wraps and mini pinches before reaching bucket jugs at the top. It could be easier to just crack climb the whole thing, but who wants to do that?

The original line avoided the large, detached flake on the left side of the boulder. However, many now opt to cam their foot in the flake and have suggested that this makes the climb a few grades easier.
content.location: It is the front line of the Sail Boulder.

content.description: Start as low as you can with your left hand in the underling crack and your right hand on a sidepull. Battle your way up the boulder till you mount the arete. Hump the boulder till you can top out.
content.location:
If facing

The Sail

, this is around the right side of the boulder. ItÂ´s a rounded arete in front of the crack of "

Tear in the Sail

".

content.description:
The Buoy is a nice warm-up that can be fun for the whole family.

Start at the bottom, and climb up the rail.
content.location: If facing The Sail, go up and left. This climbs the obvious sloper rail.
